title: MAPPING EMERGING GENDER ARTIVISM IN THE MEDITERRANEAN ARAB PUBLIC SPACE
descriptions:
**Abstract:**

The MEGAMAPS project seeks to conduct a comprehensive transnational study on Artivism for gender equality in the Mediterranean Arab public space following the 2011 uprisings. Employing an innovative interdisciplinary methodology that integrates History, Social Movements Theory, Gender Studies, Visual Arts, and Digital Humanities, the project will focus on Jordan, Lebanon, Morocco, and Tunisia. Through a combination of fieldwork and digital ethnography, MEGAMAPS aims to produce an unprecedented history from below, exploring the dynamic interplay between gender, public aesthetic dissent, and social change. This research will not only enrich global academic knowledge about the Arab region but also shed light on how Artivism serves as a political incubator, fostering egalitarian societal projects in the face of post-2011 authoritarianism. The project will culminate in academic publications and the creation of the first open-access, participatory digital platform. This platform will systematically document and interconnect a rich corpus of living sources, including visual and performative arts, oral interviews, cartographies, and graphic tools. The platform aims to innovate traditional approaches in History and Social Movements Theory, provide a dedicated research resource on Artivism, gender, and social change in the Arab region, and ensure FAIR access to these resources for academics, stakeholders, and the general public. Additionally, MEGAMAPS will facilitate a series of dissemination activities to enhance the participation of activists in a transnational network of artists, researchers, policymakers, and civil society stakeholders. These activities will promote the exchange of best practices in gender equality, arts, and democratic governance, and contribute to shifting the paradigm from victimization to agency for women and sexual minorities in the Arab region, while also challenging orientalism and islamophobia in Western public opinion.
